title: Friday Briefing: U.S. Believes Prigozhin Was Killed
description: Also, the tiny forests with big benefits.

title: Prigozhin Broke the First Rule in Russia: Don’t Defy Putin
description: The fate of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin is a reminder of all those who have paid a heavy price for standing up to President Vladimir V. Putin, and of how quickly people can fall from his favor.

title: Turkey’s Central Bank Raises Rates to Near Two-Decade High
description: The bigger-than-expected rate increase, to 25 percent, is aimed at curbing stubbornly high inflation that exceeded 80 percent last year.

title: Zimbabwe’s Ballot Delays Force Election Into 2nd Day
description: Other voters in Zimbabwe had to return the next day to vote for president, and the police raided election observers. The main candidates both predicted victory.

title: Explosion Likely Downed Plane Carrying Prigozhin, U.S. Officials Say
description: The officials stressed that other theories about what brought down a plane in Russia were still being explored.

title: Ukraine Says It Staged a Brief Raid in Occupied Crimea
description: Taking back the peninsula, which was annexed by Russia in 2014, has remained a core part of the Ukrainian war effort.

title: U.S. Says It Will Take Time to Confirm Prigozhin Was Killed in Plane Crash
description: The Wagner Group has not confirmed its leader’s death, nor has the Russian government.

title: Pentagon Plans to Begin Training Ukrainian Pilots on F-16s in U.S.
description: The decision is a shift from last week, when a U.S. official said the pilots could be trained in the United States if European training programs reached capacity.

title: As Wildfires Spread, Anger Rises in Greece Over Government Response
description: Firefighters were battling scores of blazes nationwide, but the threat to a precious woodland north of the capital had some fearing a dystopian future.

title: Ukraine Observes Another Independence Day as the War Rages On
description: On the second Independence Day since Russia’s full-scale invasion, the mood in Kyiv was subdued.

title: When Sea Ice Retreated, Some Emperor Penguins Didn’t Breed
description: New research indicates that a majority of emperor penguins in a region of Antarctica lost their chicks to sea ice melt.

title: India’s Moon Landing Offers Blueprint For Other Countries Dreaming Big
description: Its celebrated lunar landing produced not only a wave of pride at home but also a road map for other countries dreaming big.

title: A Late Summer Heat Wave Bakes Italy, France and Spain
description: In France, Spain and Italy, residents and tourists did their best to avoid scorching temperatures — again.

title: King Charles to Visit France in September, After Protests Forced Delay
description: The British monarch was supposed to make the trip in March, but widespread demonstrations over a change in the French retirement age scuttled the plan.

title: Ukraine Observes Independence Day With Subdued Celebrations
description: The Ukrainian authorities said the national holiday, which comes exactly 18 months after Russia’s full-scale invasion, won’t include public celebrations amid concerns about Russian attacks.

title: A Russian Court Extends the Pretrial Detention of Journalist Evan Gershkovich
description: A Moscow court on Thursday extended the pretrial detention of the American reporter, who has denied the espionage charges he faces. The U.S. says he has been wrongfully detained.

title: Face of Jacobite Hero ‘Bonnie Prince Charlie’ Recreated From Death Masks
description: The prince, Charles Edward Stuart, led a Jacobite rising in the Scottish Highlands in 1745. A new recreation of his face seeks to humanize the man behind the legend.

title: What We Know About the Plane Crash Linked to Wagner Chief Prigozhin
description: The Wagner mercenary group leader, who staged a short-lived mutiny against Russia’s military leadership in June, was listed as a passenger on a plane that crashed on Wednesday. Here’s what to know.

title: Ex-Principal of Australian Girls School Sentenced to 15 Years for Abuse
description: Malka Leifer, extradited from Israel after a lengthy process, was found guilty in April of sexually abusing two students decades earlier.

title: The BRICS Group Announces New Members, Expanding Its Reach
description: Argentina, Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, the U.A.E. and Saudi Arabia have been invited to join the club of emerging nations, strengthening its role as a geopolitical alternative to Western-led forums.

title: Russia-Ukraine War: Putin Remains Silent on Crash of Plane Linked to Mercenary Leader
description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, who led a brief mutiny in June, was listed as a passenger on a plane that crashed. There was no confirmation that he had died, and Russian officials including President Vladimir V. Putin did not comment on the incident.

title: Dissident Who Fled China by Jet Ski Said to Have Planned Escape for Years
description: Officials in South Korea aren’t saying who crossed 200 miles of ocean to reach its shores. But people who know Kwon Pyong say it wasn’t his first audacious move.

title: Thailand’s Old Guard Keeps Its Grip After Voters Seek Change
description: The country went months without naming a new prime minister, only for Parliament to elect Srettha Thavisin, a candidate that many frustrated voters say represents the establishment.

title: Japan Starts Releasing Radioactive Fukushima Water
description: The nuclear plant failed 12 years ago in an earthquake and tsunami, and officials say they have run out of space to store water used to cool the ruined reactors.

title: 3 Dead in Shooting at Cook’s Corner Bar in Orange County, California
description: The violence unfolded at a bar in eastern Orange County, Calif., the police said.

title: Prigozhin, Wagner Leader, Believed to Be on Plane in Deadly Russia Crash
description: All 10 people on a jet linked to Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the mercenary group, were killed on Wednesday, Russian officials said.

title: North Korea’s 2nd Satellite Launch Fails to Reach Orbit
description: The ​rocket failure was an embarrassment for the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, who badly needed a morale booster for his people.
